author: {'steamid': '76561198057456440', 'num_games_owned': 2617, 'num_reviews': 103, 'playtime_forever': 406, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 406, 'last_played': 1558602178}
review:
インディ系のメトロイドヴァニア風2Dドットパズルゲーム。
敵を倒すとその死体に乗り移ることができ、特殊能力を使って先へと進む、半アクション、半パズルのようなゲームです。
特定のモンスターでないと突破できないため、力押しでサクサク進めたいようなタイプには向かないかもしれません。

道中は部屋で区切られており、そのフロアでパズル的な謎を解きつつ次の部屋へと進めていきます。
最初はその部屋にいるモンスターを使うだけで進めますが、そのうちに動かし方や順番を考えつつギミックを操っていくため、パズル度が増していきます。
一見すると『月下の夜想曲』風な自由に探索していくように見えますが、上記のようにパズル色が強いです。

実績も色々ありますが、お腹いっぱいになってしまい、通常クリアに留めました。


＜世界観レビュー＞

良くも悪くもインディゲームらしい作りです。
敵を乗っ取って先へ進むというアイディアは光っています。
パズル的に少々もっさりしており、BGM等のゆったり感から眠くなってきます。
ただ、新しい敵がいたときどんな能力なのかな？という期待がありますので、その辺りで楽しめるかどうかでしょう。

author: {'steamid': '76561198146635403', 'num_games_owned': 346, 'num_reviews': 282, 'playtime_forever': 459, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 459, 'last_played': 1561637663}
review:
적을 죽이고 그 시체를 움직여 퍼즐을 푸는 네크로맨서 어드벤처 게임.

플레이 시간 : 7.7시간 (이건 내가 게임을 잘 못해서 오래 걸린 것...)

가성비 : 다소 높음. (90퍼 세일을 꽤 한다.)

몰입도 : 다소 높음. 

난이도 : 보통.

그리 특별할 것은 없는 어드벤처 퍼즐 게임이다. 다른 게임과의 차별성을 둔 부분을 뽑자면 적을 죽인 후 그 시체에 빙의하여 컨트롤 한다는 것이다. 게임이 진행되면서 새로운 적들이 나올수록 더 다양한 캐릭터를 사용할 수 있다. 각 챕터는 (세어보진 않았지만) 대략 12~13의 퍼즐이 있고 그 퍼즐을 다 풀면 보스전을 하게 되는데 보스의 난이도도 쉽다. 세 가지 정도의 패턴이 반복되어서 금방 잡는다. 최종보스 역시 3번만이 바로 깨버렸다. 

조작감이 나쁜 것은 아니지만 캐릭터들의 움직이는 속도가 좀 느리다. 캐릭터에 따라서 속도의 차이는 있지만 기본적으로 본체가 약간 빠르게 걷는 정도의 속도이다. 계속 죽으면서 풀어가는 퍼즐 게임의 특성상 느려서 좀 답답했다. 그게 이 게임의 흠이라고 보는 건 아니지만 개인적으로 답답한 건 어쩔 수 없다. (슈미보 정도의 빠르기를 바라는 건 아니다)

(세일을 한다면) 충분히 살만하다. 근데 애초에 다른 갓겜들 놔두고 나처럼 인디게임 파고드는 취미가 있는 게 아니라면 다른 게임을 먼저 하는 걸 추천한다. 재미있다기엔 별 감흥이 없었다.

review:
Итак, начнем по порядку:
- Перед нами один из представителей головоломки. Это определенно самое основное, что есть в игре. В начале встречает занимательная механика: переселяться в других. Авторы смогли сделать эти перевоплощения интересными, ведь у каждого существа есть свои способности. Нет загадок, которые бы заставляли запоминать огромное количество деталей. Авторы берут именно сложностью (проявляется по мере прохождения), из-за которой тебе приходится начинать уровни с начала.
- Также в игре присутствует боевка. Может быть, она не такая динамичная, но достаточно разнообразная.
- Сюжет? Эм... сюжета тут по сути почти нет. Главный герой попадает в замок, а его сопровождает всем нам знакомый "Парень в капюшоне".
- Музыка? Не отвлекает и не надоедает. Простенькие, ненавязчивые саундтреки.
- Атмосферы в игре, в общем-то, и нет. То ли я слишком концентрировался на головоломках, пока проходил одну за другой, то ли действительно никакого погружения не было. Т.е. полностью осознаешь, что это игра, а переживания появляются лишь за свое кресло из-за редких возгораний.

 По итогу у нас платформер-головоломка с интересной механикой и с хорошими загадками. Единственное, что меня изначально мучило, -  управление. Нельзя было изменить передвижения на стрелках, и прыжки героя резковаты. Но к этому привыкаешь. Наверное, минусы в этой игре слишком не значительны. Хорошая игра за свои деньги.

review: This is the peanut butter and chocolate of action/puzzle games. If this had just been a funny, retro 2-D side-scroller, it'd be a fine game. But the ability to possessed the corpses of your defeated enemies and use them to disarm traps and fight other monsters takes it to a whole other level. Some of the puzzles aren't intuitive (sharks can go up!), and the only walkthrough help I could find was in Russian, but I had a lot of fun playing this and recommend it highly.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024592582', 'num_games_owned': 768, 'num_reviews': 151, 'playtime_forever': 221, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 214, 'last_played': 1559056579}
review:
Un buen plataformas indie donde eres un chico con el poder de controlar los cadáveres de tus enemigos.

El juego se basa en dos partes, la primera son las plataformas y el combate como el chico, y la segunda son los puzzles usando las diferentes abilidades de las criaturas que has matado. La primera parte deja que desear, ya que el combate es aburrido y se hace un poco tedioso cuando tienes que repetir un puzzle varias veces. La segunda es la parte divertida del juego, combinar las posesiones para poder abrirte paso por la mazmorra.

Le doy una recomendación, buenos puzzles necrománticos, pero el combate anodino.

review:
Игру я купил за 25 рублей с учётом скидки в 90%. Так вот, поиграв в неё и пройдя, я могу сказать, что игра стоит должного внимания. 
Это тот самый платформер, который напомнил мне игру на SEGA - Adams Family.
Игра рассказывает о мальчике, который попал в неизвестный и загадочный замок с головоломками, где обитают различные монстры, а гидом по сему замку является некий мужик в капюшоне, который по ходу игры и внедряет вас в курс дела.
 Основные фишки Trials of Azra:
- много головоломок;
- интересная способность вселяться в тела мёртвых;
- ностальгия по детству,проведенному с джойстиком в руках;
- приятный сюжет (да, он тут есть).
Также в игре есть несколько крохотных отсылок и интересные достижения.

По итогу:
250 рублей за игру конечно многовато, но если дождаться скидку в 90%, а она бывает довольно-таки часто, то игра стоит своих денег и внимания.

review:
Trials of Azra is a very fun puzzle platformer in the likes of Blackthorne and The Lost Vikings.

You play as a kid named Sam who is teleported to a mysterious castle and gains the ability to resurrect and control the dead in order to solve the different puzzles in the castle.

You will go to different areas of the castle and will try to solve the puzzle in each room while collecting money to upgrade the health and mana pools and buy new spells and abilities (not mandatory to finish the game) and in the end will fight a boss.

The game is not very long but will still leave you satisfied at the end, it’s highly recommended to people who liked The Lost Vikings.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966548041', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 103, 'playtime_forever': 482, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 482, 'last_played': 1531434784}
review:
Grabbed it real quick without paying much attention to the details other than "it's cheap" and "it looks like a cute little Metroidvania to waste and afternoon on".

Well it ain't a Metroidvania.  It presents itself as a bit of one, or at least an action-platformer, but it's a puzzle game through and through.  Well, adventure-puzzle more than arcade-puzzle, but still.  Your default weapon acting like a Metroid or Mega Man-esque buster shot and all the spells and upgrades you can get may make you assume that you're going to be in for at least somewhat of a classic action romp, but trust me, those tools are essentially only there to get you started in each room (you have to kill a monster first to use the main gimmick) and for bosses.  99% of the game is made up of possessing slain enemies (and often using them to slay and possess other enemies) and using their unique abilities to solve puzzles on a room-by-room basis.

At first, I was disappointed in this, since I was hungry for more straightforward action and frankly, the presentation was far from enough to interest me on its own (you have that kind of weak faux-8bit generic indie game graphic style and an odd, eerie type of soundtrack) but... I found myself coming back again and again.  I said I'd play 10 minutes, and played an hour.  I said I'd play once today, and played thrice.  I couldn't stay gone for long 'till I had the whole game under my belt.  The puzzles are just really well-designed and fluid compared to so many indie games I've tried, challenging but never too frustrating.  They do tend to require a rigidly specific set of choices to be made and some of them end up being reasonably long and carry the risk of leaving you stuck and having to restart the room if you fail, but luckily once you know how to solve a room getting back to where you left off is a speedy process.  Oh, and the story is light, but ends up being a little more interesting than expected in the end, which is nice.

Don't expect your socks to be blown off, but if you're looking for a nice bite of puzzle solving with well-balanced difficulty, some basic but fairly decent combat, and enough meat on the bone to be satisfying without overstaying its welcome, give this game a go.

review:
Trials of Azura is a nice idea, but with poor execution. As the trailer states you get to take over the dead bodies of monsters and use them to your own devices.

In reality, you just use them to complete various button pushing and level flipping to proceed. Oddly, I found killing the enemies to be entirely pointless to the puzzle gameplay. Enemies offer no challange and just serve as pieces to the puzzle. Nothing more, nothing less. The devs could have just had dead bodies laying about and the gameplay would have remained the same. Many times the game forces you to restart levels because you dropped a body in the wrong place. Its more trial and error rather than "ah hah!" moments found in other puzzle-platformer games like Braid, DYO, Thomas Was Alone, and so on.

If you're a sucker for novel concepts (like me), you may be tempted to buy Trials of Azra. But behind the veneer of a cool idea is a bland game.

review:
A cute and quick puzzle platformer. Take control of your enemies and use their abilities to guide your character through the stages.

Use a rat to sneak through a tight space. Use a fireball-throwing imp to light some torches. Hitch a ride on a golem's back to pass deadly spikes!

It's about 2-4 hours long, but has some replay value through achievements. The game is split into several worlds, with each giving an achivement for beating it without any deaths.

Not sure if it's worth the full $10, but I got it on sale, and am very happy with my purchase.

Pros:
- Premise: I loved the possession mechanic.

Cons:
- Controls: They're a bit finicky at times. Sometimes the character won't jump if you are too close to a wall, etc. But the levels are short, so any accidental deaths are easily forgotten.. unless you are going for the no-death achievements.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970106610', 'num_games_owned': 307, 'num_reviews': 126, 'playtime_forever': 268, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 126, 'last_played': 1531237034}
review:
Je n'aime pas vraiment les jeux puzzle, mais ici on nous demande une petite dose de dextérité à la manette (sauts, timing dans les déplacements, esquives) ce qui rend le jeu moins rigide, moins fermé - comme on peut en avoir l'habitude dans ce type de jeux.

Les graphismes sont simplistes voire grossiers, surtout pour les décors ; mais les monstres sont mignons et ont des gueules sympathiques. La musique aussi est plutôt cool, plutôt originale. 

Niveau gameplay on a des mécaniques intéressantes puisqu'on doit contrôler les monstres qu'on a tués pour trouver la sortie... Certains ont des sorts classiques comme une boule de feu et un saut mais d'autres proposent des choses différentes, peu habituelles - que vous découvrirez au fil du jeu.
Les niveaux eux aussi ont des 'sorts', comme un laser qui se balade de haut en bas (classique) et (encore) d'autres choses plus originales[...] Globalement, le level design est cool et propose un challenge augmentant en difficulté au fil de la progression, avec un boss à la fin de chaque monde. Pour l'instant je n'ai vu que le premier et le combat était sympathique.

Le petit souci, c'est la caméra qui est pas très bien gérée, qui n'est pas très fluide avec quelques sensations d'à-coups.
Dans l'ensemble, la réalisation du jeu n'est pas excellente mais le jeu ne le paie pas trop cher.

Je le recommande parce que c'est un bon puzzle game ; mais je le recommanderais plus pour les adeptes du genre, sinon on peut décrocher.

author: {'steamid': '76561198077806241', 'num_games_owned': 579, 'num_reviews': 112, 'playtime_forever': 117, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 117, 'last_played': 1489808181}
review:
Azra is a switch-and-place in game the spirit of old-school PC platform puzzlers like The Lost Vikings. A competant game with some good atmosphere, but also perhaps in need of some polish and balance. The main mechanic is strong, but the level design is begging for someone like, well, Valve to refine it overall.

The focus is on puzzles rather than combat and the slow, awkward attacks make that very clear. Each room has a set number of enemies and pretty specific order to do things with a restart mechanic to drive it home. Think of enemies as tools; this is a thinker, not a fighter.

But then the action picks up or a platform segment is especially tricky and it turns into a Mario game which is a bit jarring. Azra is indie retro the way it should be, but it never quite finds a groove. It's basically excellent for its scale, but you may find yourself wanting more or noticing missed opportunities. However, if you're new to the puzzle-platform genre, or it happens to be a favorite, you'll be very pleased to give this one a go. ★☆☆

author: {'steamid': '76561197972490605', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 27, 'playtime_forever': 648, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 648, 'last_played': 1484428471}
review:
Hay montones de juegos indies que apelan a la nostalgia y Trials of Azra no es una excepción. Todo en él tiene un regustillo retro simpaticón que hará las delicias de los más viejales. Por suerte, no se limita a fotocopiar a los clásicos y se saca de la manga un sistema muy resultón que le da una vidilla inesperada: el protagonista puede poseer a los enemigos muertos y adquirir sus habilidades mientras se lleva de paseo sus cuerpos. 

A priori parece un plataformas ligero, pero en realidad toda la miga jugable se la llevan los puzles. En Trials of Azra no hay saltos con mala leche ni exploración metroidvaniesca: la dificultad se debe exclusivamente a encontrar las combinaciones correctas de enemigos poseídos para abrirnos camino hasta la salida. El desarrollo es lineal -salvo un momento puntual- y la exigencia de los niveles muy paulatina. Hay cuatro zonas divididas en muchos escenarios, plagadas de todo tipo de enemigos; de forma constante encontraremos nuevos peligros y monstruos que nos obligarán a repensar nuestras habilidades nigromanticas. 

Quizá se le puede echar en cara que abusa demasiado del sistema de posesión de monstruos, descuidando todo lo demás.La compra de mejoras -un poco forzada- o la pasividad de algunos enemigos enturbian un poco el ritmo, que por lo demás es fantástico. Salvo algunos niveles finales que obligan a repetir secciones largas, castigando el más mínimo error, todo el diseño es inteligente y original. 

Es difícil destacar entre toda la marea de jueguines indies pixelados, y Trials of Azra llama la atención precisamente por aportar un desarrollo original y no limitarse a jugar la carta de la nostalgia. Quizá tenga un par de detalles que lo alejen de la genialidad, pero merece la pena. Es divertido, simpático y exigente, sin ser frustrante. 

Pero sobre todo, lo más importante, es que te da la posibilidad de ser una rana ninja. ¿Por qué leches no lo has comprado ya?

author: {'steamid': '76561198149009729', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2415, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 411, 'last_played': 1570420033}
review:
"Uniqueness" is an extremely rare adjective within the world of platform video games. Trials of Azra is a puzzle platform hybrid that accentuates the phrase "stands out among the crowd"... The story begins with a young lad named Sam playing "fetch" with his pet pug. It's a fantastic day for fun n' games until a storm front moves in... All of a sudden, lightning strikes and we find Sam and his beloved pet deceased on the ground. Somehow Sam recovers and is able to possess the body of his pug, using him to help out with the tutorial puzzle. Unfortunately, Sam is unable to make his way inside due to a vortex portal swallowing him and transporting the boy to an outer worldly realm. Upon arrival in this strange new world, Sam learns (from a cloaked individual no less) that he now has the ability to possess the corpse of dead creatures, which will prove useful in his travels through this strange domain.

Trials of Azra's crowning jewel is it's core gameplay mechanic... Possessing the prowess of different creatures in order to safely navigate Sam through the many labyrinths in the game is essential to succeeding. At one point you may need to possess a human-like corpse; then find a way to turn said corpse into a skeleton in order to use it's ability to toss bones from it's body. Figuring out the advantages to each possession, and it's purpose for advancement, is one of the game's best feature. It's a tremendous brain teaser, from start to finish, with most stages having upgrades that provide Sam with a myriad of magic powers. Learning what power-ups effect each creature proficiently is all part of the wonderful gameplay experience that Onion Core has masterfully conjured up. There's even boss battles at the end of each stage that abandon the core mechanic for the more traditional platforming mechanic. I can't rave about the mechanics enough within this title. The controls are extremely responsive with no lag input issues at all. A very well crafted and designed title in my honest opinion.

The art and sound is superbly charming, reminding me of those classic video games found on the NES way back in the late 1980's... I truly adore the soundtrack, with each stage boasting a unique melody that fits the mood and tone ideally. If you're a fan of retro pixel titles with top notch puzzle/platform elements, I suggest you try Trials of Azra... It's definitely worth your time and gaming effort!!!

author: {'steamid': '76561198092027183', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 619, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 584, 'last_played': 1477782687}
review:
Trials of Azra is an innovative puzzle platformer that relies upon the player's ability to control dead enemies in order to progress through a series of increasingly difficult levels. 

The controls are solid and playable, although perhaps lacking the precision found in indie games like Shovel Knight. The graphics are an effective return to 16-bit era art without being a distraction. The music is well-composed and nicely suits the setting of each level. 

The game characters all feature their own unique abilities, which keeps the levels from feeling repetitive. The reward system also prevents the frustration of repeating levels already solved, while still providing additional benefits to players who die less frequently. The final boss also included some novel elements compared to other games in the genre. The story itself is kept minimal and mysterious, although the ending still provides adequate resolution to the adventure.

The style of gameplay reminded me of a combination of the Mario series with the Incredible Machine series, with elements of adventure/RPG's sprinkled into the mix. This is the right kind of game for platformer enthusiasts looking for a memorable new twist.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999576973', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 276, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 227, 'last_played': 1474233517}
review:
I've caught a glimpse of the game, it caught my eye, and so I gave it a try. It seems my instincts were correct to see that the game kept my interest as I played through it. Keep in mind, I have not finished the game, but I have played through enough to give a good word for the game. This will be a first impressions, not a full review.

The game delivers exactly what the developers put on the game's description, so I have no need to repeat it, but just for fun...

This game features:
- Unique, [strike]innocent[/strike] evil monsters to [strike]brutally murder[/strike] slay.
- Challenging puzzles and fights, not frustratingly hard.
- Iniquitous and vile wizards.
- A corrupted, demented child you play as.
- Completely legal practice of the dark arts of Necromancy.
- Kidnapping.
- A cute pug [spoiler]that you murder because you're an evil child, but its okay, it'll be your undead friend now.[/spoiler]
- Spooky skeletons.
- Completely friendly families of kobolds.
- And more...!

The general gist I get from this game is that it's an unique and charming take on the puzzle genre. The gameplay works exactly as intended, and each level brings different challenges so that it doesn't feel monotonous. The visuals and sound are fairly decent, they serve their purpose and don't sound and look terrible at all. Personally, however, while the menu music is amazing, the level music is a bit repetetive, but that can be easily turned off in the options menu. Speaking of the options menu, there's a slider for the master volume, the music, and the sound effects; video options for full screen, resolution, showing damage, and the language; and lastly controls, where you can enable keyboard and mouse with some rebindable keys. I'm not entirely sure how long the game will last you, but I've been at it for about two hours and still going. Lastly, the developers are very kind and has taken into consideration the bugs and suggestions that has been made.

Overall, this is a nice little charming gem of a game, I do recommend giving it a try if it seems to pique your interest. I will edit or add anything to this review as I play through it accordingly. If I missed anything, or if you are curious about something, do point it out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042669538', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 133, 'playtime_forever': 1310, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1306, 'last_played': 1477086317}
review:
This is a platform/adventure puzzler with 16-bit graphics. Before you say "meh" and move on, let me tell you that this game is so much more than its label suggests. I confess to having always been biased against low-res games like this in the past, I've always thought pixel graphics = basic gameplay but WOW, have my eyes been opened!

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

You play as a boy named Sam who enters a platform area. You shoot enemies and then possess their bodies (one at a time) to use their abilities to navigate past the various traps and obstacles to reach switches, pressure plates and walls to eventually make a path for Sam to reach the exit and move on to the next level.

Dead enemies drop gems to be picked up by Sam which increases his gold profit. At the end of each main area the gold can be spent at the market stall of the mysterious hooded man (who reveals himself at the end of the game) to purchase powerups (increased weapon range, more health etc), making Sam stronger to tackle subsequent areas.

Sam has 2 power bars: the normal red one for health, and a blue one to represent Mana which depletes as Sam uses his special Spells. New Spells are acquired by picking them up on certain rare levels.

Split-screen local co-op is available. You can recruit a friend to play the possessed enemies while you control Sam.

[h1]Aesthetics[/h1]

Up to 1920x1200 res, window or fullscreen. The pixel graphics are clean and sharp. I wouldn't go so far as to say beautiful but there's enough artwork to make it pleasing to the eye. The many enemies are imaginatively designed and instantly identifiable.

Background music is outstanding. There are various different tunes as you progress through the game, they are all catchy and really suit the 16-bit mood. I left it on instead of playing my own music, which is very unusual. They're the sort of tunes that stay in your head and you find yourself humming them later on.

[h1]Performance[/h1]

Smooth and responsive on both Windows and Linux. One or two disappearing-enemy glitches are easily fixed by restarting the level, rare and hardly worth mentioning. With low-res graphics this is likely to run well even on potato-class hardware. Good settings menus, everything is tweakable. Fully cross-platform.

[h1]Difficulty[/h1]

Puzzlers are my favourite thing, I've played many and consider myself a bit of an aficionado so I have a lot to compare against. The brainwork here is never easy. It starts off as medium and ramps up through difficult and very difficult. In some cases, part of the challenge is working out how the abilities of a new enemy work and how they interact with the puzzle - there are some Eureka! moments as new game mechanics are revealed. The general aim is to a) kill the enemies one by one (often using them to kill each other), b) work out a route to the exit and c) decide which enemies are the right ones to tackle each part of the puzzle and how to apply their abilities.

Controller skills: the game can be played with mouse/keyboard but I'd say a controller is mandatory. There is little or no challenge in the first 2 areas, it's very easy. The 3rd area starts introducing some difficulty and by the 4th area I was having trouble with some levels. I'm no expert with this type of thing, if you're used to coordination-oriented games you'll no doubt find it easier than I did. This aspect of the game is secondary to the puzzling anyway.

Bosses: at the end of each area is an old-school boss, the type that's very difficult at first but once you understand their attack patterns it becomes a matter of routine. The final boss (the Grim Reaper himself) is really tough!!

[h1]Con[/h1]

The only negative thing I can think of to say about this game is that during the first playthrough there's no indication of how many levels there are or how far through the game you've progressed. I've given you this info below, so now there's no con :) The devs have told me they're considering adding some kind of progress indicator in future.

Once you complete the game you can repeat whole areas (starting from the first level of the area) by going through doorways from the main entrance but there are still no numbered levels to select. This does at least make it feasible to chase the no-death achievements.

[h1]Value[/h1]

60+ levels in 4 main areas. According to the leaderboards it can be completed in 7 hours but it took me a lot longer, at a leisurely pace with a good amount of head-scratching and restarts. There is replay value in tackling achievements for no-death runs and missed pickups etc. It's not just the quantity though, the quality of puzzle design is also top-notch, the wide variety produces constant challenge so it never feels stale.

Well worth full price.

[h1]Steam[/h1]

8 trading cards; 30 achievements; cloud; leaderboards. It's got the lot.

[h1]Verdict[/h1]

Don't let the pixel graphics put you off, this is a highly accomplished puzzler and it's a joy to play. I've been waking up in the morning eager to tackle more levels and discover new enemies. You'll be hooked in no time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198322302187', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 1297, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1207, 'last_played': 1474456002}
review:
仅通关一周目约8h。
主角的能力是附身死亡的怪物，以此展开的战斗和解谜比较有趣。

[b]简评：[/b]

+2：有特色的解谜趣味性
+0.5：流程难度的递进设计
+1：成就 - 难度(耗时)适中、有趣味性

-1：不够完整的剧情
-0.5：不够好看的画面设计/音乐
-0.5：略单调的战斗要素
-1：特色过少

总：5.5/10

注：同期的像素横版游戏The Final Station我给同5.5分，至于原因看 [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/R_Masamune/recommended/435530/]这位写的[/url] 吧。


[b]详评：[/b]

从扣分项开始说。

[b][i]-1：不够完整的剧情[/i][/b]

这原本可以是加分项。
虽然原本也未必是一个很好的剧情，但目前来看不至于扣分。

但比较可惜的是，这里面的剧情太少了。
和作者交流了一下，表示主要专注于解谜上，我觉得也确实是这样。
作者表示也是希望营造一个前传式的感觉。
但作为一款完整游戏而言，剧情的讲述是少了。

截止10.03还没更新的迹象。


[b][i]-0.5：不够好看的画面设计/音乐
-0.5：略单调的战斗要素[/i][/b]

像素是我喜欢的类型。
boss的画面感觉还过得去，部分场景（比如第四章）还算好看。

但更多的还是平庸的设计。

音乐亦如此。
boss战和第四章的bgm还可以。
但更多的是一般。


[b][i]-1：特色过少[/i][/b]

这个游戏最大的问题就是特色太少。
只要再有一项出彩，按我评价就能轻松超过同期的花瓶The Final Station。


[b][i]+1：成就 - 难度(耗时)适中、有趣味性[/i][/b]

有几个成就像彩蛋一样比较好玩。
我最后解锁的隐藏成就还是看了别人解锁的描述才知道的。

后几关会遇到较多的秒杀机关，容错比较低，打怪倒是不容易死。
一个章节里有十几关，所以无死过章的成就还是有些麻烦的（不死打到十几关，然后被机关突然秒杀什么的...）。


[b][i]+2：有特色的解谜趣味性
+0.5：流程难度的递进设计[/i][/b]

过图 解谜为主（越后期越是加入些操作要素）+战斗为辅。
总体难度还可以。

前三个boss战 战斗+场景互动。
boss战比较整洁，造型上白熊火女还行，最终boss[spoiler]第二形态本体有些蠢(穿插关挺有趣)[/spoiler]。
因为过图很多，所以总体上还是解谜游戏。

前两章几乎没用翻滚，回想下还是按键的锅。
打第三章boss牛头人，翻滚很有用，第四章最终boss用翻滚也有帮助。


另外，
左右移动是固定键盘左右键，导致必须右手控制方向。
而且因为键位，导致其他动作按键都得左手完成。
个人比较习惯左手方向右手攻击...现在只能反过来了。

若是喜欢简洁的小品类解谜游戏，可考虑打折时入，或是等更新。

author: {'steamid': '76561198164306900', 'num_games_owned': 4402, 'num_reviews': 154, 'playtime_forever': 134, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 134, 'last_played': 1472491905}
review:
Trials of Azra
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Wow, What a Hidden Gem, I had never heard of this game prior to playing it, and at first look I took it with a grain of salt, but I should of never underestimated the classic that this is, this game plays very well and is actually very fun and challenging.
The game is an Adventure Puzzle Platormer with Elements of games Like Zelda, Mario and even Portal. 
It has decent music, and cool graphics, The gameplay is really where its at tho, I got lost in this game (in a good way, not actually lost) and just got so immersed in it, which is really what I look for in a good game. The Magic/Mana is done well and the best thing of all that seperates this game is the ability to raise the dead, How cool is it to kill things and then make them do your bidding lol, There are boss fights and TONS of levels. The game was well designed and is very challenging, A lot of puzzles will have you reseting the levels multiple times, I did catch a few bugs where I had to restart the level to fix, such as Teleporting somehwere you couldn't get out of etc, but for the most part the game is polished pretty well, I would absolutely recomend this to people who are fans of a good challenge like the portal games, those who like playing with the dead, and platforming fans alike. 
This is My Game Of Month for sure, Hope to see a sequel in the future.


Pros:
+ Full Controller Support
+ Cool Platforming
+ Nice Mana Mechanics
+ Local Co Op
+ Acievements
+ Addicting Gameplay

Cons:
- NO Trading Cards
- Minor Glitches Occasionally

author: {'steamid': '76561198142068454', 'num_games_owned': 203, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 100, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 100, 'last_played': 1470363235}
review:
Debo ser sincero y decir que mis expectativas eran bajas simplemente por que me deje llevar y lo prejuzgue por su apariencia simple, sin embargo a la hora de jugarlo encontré un gran ejemplo de equilibrio entre diversos elementos que muchos desarrolladores deberían aprender.

El juego comienza con un tutorial bastante disimulado, (debo decirlo así por que soy la clase de persona que siempre saltea todos los tutoriales), ya que experiencia es mejor cuando vamos aprendiendo ingame y eso es exactamente lo que hace Trials of Azra: Comienzas en ese soleado día jugando con tu perro en el patio de tu casa, mientras vas aprendiendo los controles básicos hasta que de pronto una fuerte tormenta aparece de la nada causando la muerte de tu perro y a modo de compensación brindandote unas especies de habilidades de lo mas curiosas; Aca es donde aparece el primer puzzle que es de lo mas simple pero efectivo ya que nos presenta como es el mecanismo del juego y el objetivo de cada nivel: “Encontrar la forma de salir” utilizando principalmente las habilidades y dimensiones de los cuerpos que podemos poseer debido a ese extraño poder macabro que hemos adquirido.

Tras todo esto y la indagación posterior en una especie de extraño mundo del que no sabemos porque razón estamos ahí (o por lo menos hasta donde llegue a jugarlo) , quede hechizado y el diseño que me parecía simple resulto ser totalmente genial; Tras resolver cada puzzle fui notando que el juego tiene un componente excelente y olvidado en muchas ocasiones por muchos desarrolladores: Es el hecho de hacer una jugabilidad que sea equilibrada, desafiante y a su vez que vaya educando al jugador para superar los futuros retos, esto especialmente sin tratar al jugador como un estúpido dándole demasiadas indicaciones de como realizar cada acción (Muchos juegos en la actualidad lo hacen), si no haciendo que el mismo jugador sea capaz de diferenciar y entender la función de cada elemento del juego.

La idea de tener la posibilidad de poseer a cada enemigo nos da una especie de jugabilidad única, compleja y amplia, ya que cada puzzle nos obliga a utilizar las habilidades del enemigo (que poseemos claro) para superar esas distintas zonas por las que nosotros no podemos cruzar o que son demasiado riesgosas.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981008901', 'num_games_owned': 1093, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 592, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 415, 'last_played': 1471958554}
review:
I've pretty much been hooked on Trials of Azra since I started playing. It has a good difficulty curve and the puzzles are engaging and really put your brain (and reflexes) to work. The controls are polished, the graphics are good, and the enemies are cute and varied, with different abilities that of course you have to use to finish each level.

ToA is a game that keeps you playing I think, it does something that makes it approachable in the sense that you know you're close to doing a perfect level, you just need to focus. 

Most levels can be finished quick as long as you know what to do, while the boss fights are longer but don't drag on. 

I haven't played in co-op so I can't say how that is. The singleplayer though, is solid. You can see gameplay in the video below, more on my channel.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069987774', 'num_games_owned': 134, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 347, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 160, 'last_played': 1538522072}
review:
I got quickly involved with this game. On the surface, it may seem like any other retro platformer out there, but at the very first 15-20 minutes of the game, you can already tell the really well thought puzzle aspect, mixed with the unique mechanic to possess your fallen enemies. 
It's very complete for an Early Access title, and definitely worth my while (still is, as I haven't finished it).
Aside from the puzzle design (which I've fallen in love from the start), there's a sense of humor most noticeable on the dialogs and some of the environment that goes really well with the aesthetics.
Recommended!
